overview.title: Overview - General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
overview.content:
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is the European Union's comprehensive data protection law that came into effect on 25 May 2018. It replaced the 1995 Data Protection Directive and represents one of the most significant data protection frameworks globally, setting the standard for privacy legislation worldwide.

Purpose and Background

The GDPR was designed to harmonize data protection laws across EU member states and strengthen individuals' rights regarding their personal data. It addresses the challenges posed by rapid technological developments, globalization, and the increasing flow of personal data across borders. The regulation aims to give EU citizens control over their personal data while simplifying the regulatory environment for international business.

The GDPR was adopted on 27 April 2016 after four years of preparation and debate, and became enforceable on 25 May 2018. It applies directly to all EU member states without requiring national implementing legislation, though member states can introduce specific provisions in certain areas.

Key Features

1. Territorial Scope: Applies to processing of personal data of EU residents, regardless of where the controller/processor is located
2. Comprehensive Rights: Grants data subjects extensive rights over their personal data
3. Strict Obligations: Imposes detailed obligations on controllers and processors
4. Accountability Principle: Requires organizations to demonstrate compliance
5. Data Protection by Design: Requires privacy to be built into systems from the start
6. Breach Notification: Mandatory notification of data breaches within 72 hours
7. Significant Penalties: Fines up to €20 million or 4% of annual turnover
8. Data Protection Officers: Mandatory DPOs for certain organizations

Historical Context

The GDPR evolved from the 1995 Data Protection Directive, which was the EU's first comprehensive data protection law. The directive required implementation by member states, leading to inconsistent application. The GDPR was created to:
- Harmonize data protection across the EU
- Address modern data processing challenges
- Strengthen individual rights
- Simplify compliance for international businesses
- Set a global standard for data protection

The GDPR has influenced data protection laws worldwide, including India's DPDPA 2023, Brazil's LGPD, and California's CCPA.

Relationship to Other Laws

The GDPR works alongside:
- ePrivacy Directive: For electronic communications privacy
- Law Enforcement Directive: For processing by law enforcement
- National Laws: Member states can introduce specific provisions
- Sectoral Legislation: Specific rules for certain sectors (e.g., health, finance)

Significance

The GDPR is significant because:
- It's one of the most comprehensive data protection laws globally
- It has extraterritorial reach - applies to organizations worldwide if they process EU residents' data
- It sets a high standard that has influenced laws globally
- It grants individuals strong rights over their data
- It imposes significant penalties for non-compliance
- It requires privacy by design and default

For organizations processing personal data of EU residents, GDPR compliance is mandatory, regardless of where the organization is located. The regulation has become a global benchmark for data protection.

definitions.title: Definitions
definitions.content: Key definitions from Article 4 of the GDPR.
definitions.laymanExplanation: The GDPR defines key terms that determine rights and obligations. Personal Data is any information about an identified or identifiable person (name, email, IP address, etc.). Processing is any operation on personal data (collecting, storing, using, sharing, deleting, etc.). Controller is the organization that decides why and how to process data. Processor is the organization that processes data on behalf of the controller. Data Subject is the person whose data is processed. Consent must be freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous. Personal Data Breach is a security incident leading to unauthorized access, loss, or disclosure of personal data. Understanding these definitions is crucial because your obligations depend on which role you play (controller vs processor) and what type of data you process.
definitions.crossMapping: DPDPA Comparison: GDPR's 'controller' and 'processor' concepts influenced DPDPA's 'Data Fiduciary' and 'Data Processor'. IT Act Comparison: GDPR's 'processor' is similar to IT Act's 'intermediary' in some contexts. Key Similarity: All frameworks define roles and responsibilities for data processing, though terminology differs.

subsections.title: Personal Data
subsections.content: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
subsections.bareActText: (1) 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('data subject'); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person;
subsections.laymanExplanation: Personal data is any information about a person who can be identified (directly or indirectly). This includes obvious things like name, email, phone number, but also less obvious things like IP address, cookie ID, location data, or even a combination of information that together can identify someone. The definition is very broad - almost any information about a person counts as personal data.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA 'Personal Data': Similar broad definition. Key Similarity: Both define personal data broadly to include any information that can identify a person.

subsections.title: Controller
subsections.content: The entity that determines the purposes and means of processing personal data.
subsections.bareActText: (7) 'controller' means the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data; where the purposes and means of such processing are determined by Union or Member State law, the controller or the specific criteria for its nomination may be provided for by Union or Member State law;
subsections.laymanExplanation: A Controller is the organization that decides why and how to process personal data. For example, if a company collects customer data to provide services, the company is the Controller. Controllers have primary responsibility for compliance - they must ensure processing is lawful, respect data subject rights, implement security measures, and notify breaches. Think of them as the 'decision maker' for data processing.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA 'Data Fiduciary': Similar concept - entity that determines purposes and means. Key Similarity: Both have primary responsibility for compliance.

subsections.title: Processor
subsections.content: The entity that processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
subsections.bareActText: (8) 'processor' means a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller;
subsections.laymanExplanation: A Processor is an organization that processes personal data on behalf of a Controller. For example, if a company (Controller) hires a cloud storage provider (Processor) to store customer data, the cloud provider is the Processor. Processors must follow the Controller's instructions, implement security measures, and assist with compliance, but the Controller remains primarily responsible. Think of them as a 'service provider' for data processing.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA 'Data Processor': Identical concept. IT Act 'Intermediary': Similar concept in some contexts. Key Similarity: All frameworks recognize entities that process data on behalf of others.

subsections.title: Processing
subsections.content: Any operation performed on personal data, whether automated or not.
subsections.bareActText: (2) 'processing' means any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means, such as collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction;
subsections.laymanExplanation: Processing is any operation on personal data - collecting, storing, using, sharing, analyzing, deleting, etc. It's a very broad term that covers almost anything you do with personal data. Even just storing data counts as processing. This broad definition ensures the GDPR covers all data handling activities.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA 'Processing': Similar broad definition. Key Similarity: Both define processing broadly to cover all data operations.

subsections.title: Consent
subsections.content: Freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes.
subsections.bareActText: (11) 'consent' of the data subject means any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her;
subsections.laymanExplanation: Consent must be: (1) Freely given - You can't be forced or tricked. (2) Specific - You're agreeing to something particular. (3) Informed - You know what you're agreeing to. (4) Unambiguous - You must clearly say yes (like clicking a button), not just by staying silent. Pre-checked boxes don't count. You must actively agree. This ensures consent is meaningful and not just assumed.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 6: Similar consent requirements. Key Similarity: Both require clear, affirmative consent.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding key definitions helps determine your role and obligations under the GDPR.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
Key Definitions Explained

Personal Data: Any information about a person who can be identified (name, email, IP address, etc.). Very broad definition.

Processing: Any operation on personal data (collecting, storing, using, sharing, deleting, etc.). Also very broad.

Controller: Organization that decides why and how to process data. Has primary responsibility for compliance.

Processor: Organization that processes data on behalf of a Controller. Must follow Controller's instructions.

Data Subject: The person whose data is processed.

Consent: Must be freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous. You must actively agree.

Personal Data Breach: Security incident leading to unauthorized access, loss, or disclosure of personal data.

Why This Matters: Your obligations depend on which role you play (Controller vs Processor) and what type of data you process. Understanding these definitions is crucial for compliance.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR definitions can be compared with similar concepts in other frameworks.
subsections.crossMapping:
DPDPA Comparison:
- GDPR's 'controller' ≈ DPDPA's 'Data Fiduciary'
- GDPR's 'processor' ≈ DPDPA's 'Data Processor'
- GDPR's 'personal data' ≈ DPDPA's 'personal data'
- GDPR's 'consent' ≈ DPDPA's 'consent'
- Both have similar definitions and concepts

IT Act Comparison:
- GDPR's 'processor' is similar to IT Act's 'intermediary' in some contexts
- Both recognize entities that handle data on behalf of others

Key Takeaway: GDPR's definitions have influenced data protection laws globally, including DPDPA. The concepts are similar, though terminology may differ.

applicability.title: Applicability
applicability.content:
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) applies to:

1. Subject Matter and Objectives (Article 1): This Regulation lays down rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and rules relating to the free movement of personal data.

2. Material Scope (Article 2): This Regulation applies to the processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and to the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system.

3. Territorial Scope (Article 3): Processing of personal data by controllers and processors established in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not; or processing of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union by a controller or processor not established in the Union, where the processing activities are related to offering goods/services or monitoring behavior.
applicability.bareActText:
Article 1 - Subject-matter and objectives

(1) This Regulation lays down rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and rules relating to the free movement of personal data.

(2) This Regulation protects fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and in particular their right to the protection of personal data.

(3) The free movement of personal data within the Union shall be neither restricted nor prohibited for reasons connected with the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

Article 2 - Material scope

(1) This Regulation applies to the processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and to the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system.

(2) This Regulation does not apply to the processing of personal data:
(a) in the course of an activity which falls outside the scope of Union law;
(b) by the Member States when carrying out activities which fall within the scope of Chapter 2 of Title V of the TEU;
(c) by a natural person in the course of a purely personal or household activity;
(d) by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security.

Article 3 - Territorial scope

(1) This Regulation applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not.

(2) This Regulation applies to the processing of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union by a controller or processor not established in the Union, where the processing activities are related to:
(a) the offering of goods or services, irrespective of whether a payment of the data subject is required, to such data subjects in the Union; or
(b) the monitoring of their behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the Union.

(3) This Regulation applies to the processing of personal data by a controller not established in the Union, but in a place where Member State law applies by virtue of public international law.
applicability.laymanExplanation: The GDPR applies broadly to protect EU residents' data, regardless of where the company is located. It applies if: (1) Company in EU - Any company established in the EU must comply, even if processing happens outside the EU. (2) Serving EU residents - Companies outside the EU must comply if they offer goods/services to EU residents or monitor their behavior. (3) International law - In certain international contexts. This means a US company selling to EU customers must comply with GDPR, even though it's not in the EU. This extraterritorial reach is one of GDPR's most significant features.
applicability.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 3: Similar territorial scope - applies to processing in India or targeting Indian residents. IT Act Section 1(2): Similar approach - applies to offences affecting India. Key Similarity: All use territorial scope to ensure laws apply to activities affecting their jurisdiction. Key Difference: GDPR explicitly covers offering goods/services and monitoring behavior, which is more detailed than some other laws.

subsections.title: Territorial Scope
subsections.content: The GDPR applies to processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not.
subsections.bareActText: Article 3(1) This Regulation applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If your company has any presence in the EU (office, branch, subsidiary), GDPR applies to all your data processing, even if the actual processing happens outside the EU. For example, if a US company has an office in Germany, GDPR applies to all its data processing worldwide, not just what happens in Germany.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 3: Similar concept - applies to processing in India. Key Similarity: Both apply based on establishment in the jurisdiction.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding when GDPR applies helps determine your compliance obligations.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
When Does GDPR Apply?

The GDPR applies if:

Company in EU: Any company with an office/branch in the EU must comply, even if processing happens outside the EU

Serving EU Residents: Companies outside the EU must comply if they:
- Offer goods or services to EU residents (like selling products online)
- Monitor EU residents' behavior (like tracking website visits)

Key Point: GDPR has extraterritorial reach - it applies to companies worldwide if they serve EU residents. This means a US or Indian company selling to EU customers must comply with GDPR.

Why This Matters: Understanding applicability is crucial for compliance. If GDPR applies to you, you must follow all its requirements, regardless of where your company is located.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR's applicability can be compared with similar territorial scope provisions.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 3: Similar territorial scope - applies to processing in India or targeting Indian residents. IT Act Section 1(2): Similar approach - applies to offences affecting India. Key Takeaway: GDPR's territorial scope is similar to modern data protection laws, ensuring comprehensive coverage of data processing affecting EU residents.

stakeholders.title: Stakeholders
stakeholders.content:
The GDPR identifies the following key stakeholders:

1. Data Subject: An identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed.

2. Controller: The natural or legal person, public authority, agency, or other body which determines the purposes and means of processing.

3. Joint Controllers (Article 26): Where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing, they shall be joint controllers.

4. Processor: A natural or legal person, public authority, agency, or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.

5. Representative (Article 27): Controllers or processors not established in the Union must designate a representative in the Union.

6. Data Protection Officer (DPO): An expert on data protection who assists the controller or processor in monitoring compliance.

7. Supervisory Authority: An independent public authority established by a Member State to monitor the application of the GDPR.
stakeholders.bareActText:
Article 4(1) 'data subject' means an identified or identifiable natural person whose personal data is processed;

Article 4(7) 'controller' means the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data;

Article 4(8) 'processor' means a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller;

Article 26 - Joint controllers

(1) Where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing, they shall be joint controllers. They shall in a transparent manner determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the obligations under this Regulation, in particular as regards the exercising of the rights of the data subject and their respective duties to provide the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14, by means of an arrangement between them unless, and in so far as, the respective responsibilities of the controllers are determined by Union or Member State law to which the controllers are subject.

Article 27 - Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union

(1) Where Article 3(2) applies, the controller or the processor shall designate in writing a representative in the Union.

(2) The obligation laid down in paragraph 1 of this Article shall not apply to:
(a) processing which is occasional, does not include, on a large scale, processing of special categories of data pursuant to Article 9(1) or processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10, and is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, taking into account the nature, context, scope and purposes of the processing; or
(b) a public authority or body.

(3) The representative shall be established in one of the Member States where the data subjects, whose personal data are processed in relation to the offering of goods or services to them, or whose behaviour is monitored, are located.

(4) The representative shall be mandated by the controller or processor to be addressed in addition to or instead of the controller or the processor by, in particular, supervisory authorities and data subjects, on all issues related to processing, for the purposes of ensuring compliance with this Regulation.

Article 37 - Designation of the data protection officer

(1) The controller and the processor shall designate a data protection officer in any case where:
(a) the processing is carried out by a public authority or body, except for courts acting in their judicial capacity;
(b) the core activities of the controller or the processor consist of processing operations which, by virtue of their nature, their scope and/or their purposes, require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale; or
(c) the core activities of the controller or the processor consist of processing on a large scale of special categories of data pursuant to Article 9 or of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10.

Article 51 - Supervisory authority

(1) Each Member State shall provide for one or more independent public authorities to be responsible for monitoring the application of this Regulation, in order to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons in relation to processing and to facilitate the free flow of personal data within the Union.
stakeholders.laymanExplanation: The GDPR defines different roles: Data Subject is the person whose data is processed (you). Controller is the company that decides why and how to process data - they have primary responsibility. Joint Controllers are two or more companies that together decide how to process data - they must agree on responsibilities. Processor is a service provider that processes data on behalf of the Controller (like cloud storage). Representative is a person/company in the EU that represents non-EU controllers/processors - required for companies outside the EU serving EU residents. Data Protection Officer (DPO) is an expert who helps ensure compliance - required for certain organizations. Supervisory Authority is the government body in each EU country that enforces GDPR. Your obligations depend on which role you play - Controllers have the most responsibilities.
stakeholders.crossMapping: DPDPA Comparison: Controller ≈ Data Fiduciary, Processor ≈ Data Processor. IT Act Comparison: Processor ≈ Intermediary in some contexts. Key Similarity: All frameworks define roles and allocate responsibilities accordingly.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding stakeholder roles helps determine your responsibilities.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
Who Are the Stakeholders?

Data Subject: The person whose data is processed (you)

Controller: The company that decides why and how to process data. They have primary responsibility for compliance.

Joint Controllers: Two or more companies that together decide how to process data. They must agree on who does what and inform data subjects.

Processor: A service provider that processes data on behalf of the Controller (like cloud storage, payment processors). They must follow the Controller's instructions.

Representative: A person/company in the EU that represents non-EU controllers/processors. Required for companies outside the EU that serve EU residents (unless processing is occasional and low-risk).

Data Protection Officer (DPO): An expert who helps ensure compliance. Required for:
- Public authorities
- Companies that monitor people on a large scale
- Companies that process sensitive data on a large scale

Supervisory Authority: Government body in each EU country that enforces GDPR (like ICO in UK, CNIL in France)

Why This Matters: Your obligations depend on which role you play. Controllers have the most responsibilities, while Processors must follow instructions and assist with compliance.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR stakeholder roles can be compared with similar concepts.
subsections.crossMapping:
DPDPA Comparison:
- Controller ≈ Data Fiduciary (determines purposes and means)
- Processor ≈ Data Processor (processes on behalf of fiduciary)
- Both have similar role-based responsibility models
- GDPR's 'Representative' concept is similar to DPDPA's requirement for certain entities to have representatives in India

IT Act Comparison:
- Processor ≈ Intermediary (handles data on behalf of others)
- Similar liability protections

Key Takeaway: GDPR's stakeholder model has influenced data protection laws globally, including DPDPA. The concepts are similar, though terminology may differ. GDPR's joint controller and representative concepts provide additional clarity for complex scenarios.

rights.title: Rights of Data Subjects
rights.content:
The GDPR grants data subjects the following rights:

1. Right of Access: Right to obtain confirmation and access to personal data.

2. Right to Rectification: Right to have inaccurate personal data rectified.

3. Right to Erasure ('Right to be Forgotten'): Right to have personal data erased under certain conditions.

4. Right to Restriction of Processing: Right to restrict processing under certain circumstances.

5. Right to Data Portability: Right to receive personal data in a structured, commonly used format.

6. Right to Object: Right to object to processing of personal data.

7. Rights Related to Automated Decision-Making: Rights regarding automated individual decision-making, including profiling.
rights.bareActText:
Article 15 - Right of access by the data subject

The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning him or her are being processed, and, where that is the case, access to the personal data and the following information.

Article 16 - Right to rectification

The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her.

Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and the controller shall have the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies.

Article 18 - Right to restriction of processing

The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing where one of the following applies.

Article 20 - Right to data portability

The data subject shall have the right to receive the personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance from the controller to which the personal data have been provided.

Article 21 - Right to object

The data subject shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her.

Article 22 - Automated individual decision-making, including profiling

The data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her.
rights.laymanExplanation: The GDPR gives you strong rights over your personal data: (1) Right to Know - You can ask companies what data they have about you. (2) Right to Correct - You can ask them to fix inaccurate data. (3) Right to Delete - You can ask them to delete your data in certain situations (the famous 'right to be forgotten'). (4) Right to Restrict - You can ask them to stop processing your data in certain situations. (5) Right to Portability - You can get your data in a format you can use elsewhere (like moving your data from one service to another). (6) Right to Object - You can object to certain types of processing. (7) Right Regarding Automated Decisions - You have rights regarding decisions made by algorithms. These rights give you control over your data.
rights.crossMapping: DPDPA Comparison: Similar rights (access, correction, erasure, grievance). DPDPA doesn't have explicit data portability or restriction rights. Key Similarity: Both grant individuals control over their data. Key Difference: GDPR has more detailed rights (portability, restriction, automated decision-making).

subsections.title: Right to Erasure
subsections.content:
Data subjects have the right to obtain erasure of personal data where:
- The data is no longer necessary for the original purpose
- The data subject withdraws consent
- The data subject objects to processing
- The data has been unlawfully processed
- Erasure is required for compliance with legal obligations
subsections.laymanExplanation: You can ask companies to delete your data if: (1) It's no longer needed, (2) You withdraw consent, (3) You object to processing, (4) It was processed illegally, or (5) Law requires deletion. This is the famous 'right to be forgotten' - you can ask companies to remove your data from their systems. However, there are exceptions (like if they need it for legal claims).
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 12: Similar right to erasure, though DPDPA focuses on data no longer necessary. Key Similarity: Both allow deletion of personal data under certain conditions.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding your rights helps you take control of your personal data.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
What Are Your Data Rights Under GDPR?

Right to Know: You can ask companies what data they have about you and what they're doing with it.

Right to Correct: You can ask them to fix inaccurate data.

Right to Delete: You can ask them to delete your data (the 'right to be forgotten').

Right to Restrict: You can ask them to stop processing your data in certain situations.

Right to Portability: You can get your data in a format you can use elsewhere (like moving from one service to another).

Right to Object: You can object to certain types of processing.

Right Regarding Automated Decisions: You have rights regarding decisions made by algorithms.

Why This Matters: These rights give you control over your personal data. Companies must respond to your requests and can't ignore them.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR rights can be compared with similar rights in other frameworks.
subsections.crossMapping:
DPDPA Comparison:
- GDPR Right of Access ≈ DPDPA Right to Access (Section 11)
- GDPR Right to Rectification ≈ DPDPA Right to Correction (Section 12)
- GDPR Right to Erasure ≈ DPDPA Right to Erasure (Section 12)
- GDPR Right to Object ≈ DPDPA Right to Grievance (Section 13)
- GDPR has additional rights (Portability, Restriction, Automated Decisions) that DPDPA doesn't explicitly include

Key Takeaway: GDPR has more comprehensive rights, while DPDPA focuses on core rights. Both empower individuals with control over their data.

obligations.title: Obligations of Controllers and Processors
obligations.content:
The GDPR imposes comprehensive obligations on controllers and processors:

1. Principles of Processing (Article 5): Process data lawfully, fairly, transparently, for specific purposes, minimized, accurate, and secure.

2. Lawfulness of Processing (Article 6): Process only on lawful bases (consent, contract, legal obligation, vital interests, public task, legitimate interests).

3. Conditions for Consent (Article 7): Consent must be demonstrable, easily withdrawable, and not a condition for contract performance.

4. Child's Consent (Article 8): For children under 16, consent must be given by holder of parental responsibility.

5. Transparent Information (Article 12): Provide information in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form.

6. Information to be Provided (Articles 13-14): Provide specific information when collecting data directly or indirectly.

7. Responsibility of Controller (Article 24): Implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure compliance.

8. Data Protection by Design and by Default (Article 25): Build privacy into systems from the start.

9. Processor (Article 28): Processors must process only on documented instructions and implement security measures.

10. Security of Processing (Article 32): Implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure security.

11. Data Protection Impact Assessment (Article 35): Conduct DPIAs for high-risk processing.

12. Records of Processing Activities (Article 30): Maintain records of processing activities.

13. Data Breach Notification (Articles 33-34): Notify supervisory authority and data subjects of breaches.

14. Data Protection Officer (Articles 37-39): Appoint a DPO in certain circumstances.
obligations.laymanExplanation: The GDPR imposes comprehensive obligations on companies: (1) Principles - Data must be processed lawfully, fairly, transparently, for specific purposes, minimized, accurate, and secure. (2) Lawful Basis - You can only process data if you have a valid reason (consent, contract, legal requirement, etc.). (3) Consent Requirements - Consent must be demonstrable, easily withdrawable, and not a condition for services. (4) Child Protection - For children under 16, need parental consent. (5) Transparency - Provide clear, understandable information about processing. (6) Information Requirements - Tell people what data you collect, why, how long you keep it, and their rights. (7) Controller Responsibility - Implement measures to ensure compliance. (8) Privacy by Design - Build privacy into systems from the start. (9) Processor Requirements - Processors must follow controller's instructions and implement security. (10) Security Measures - Implement appropriate technical and organizational security measures. (11) Impact Assessments - Assess risks for high-risk processing. (12) Records - Keep records of what data you process and why. (13) Breach Notification - Tell authorities within 72 hours and affected people if high risk. (14) Data Protection Officer - Appoint a DPO for certain organizations. These obligations ensure companies handle data responsibly.
obligations.crossMapping: DPDPA Comparison: Similar obligations (lawful basis, security, breach notification). DPDPA is more streamlined, while GDPR is more detailed. Key Similarity: Both require lawful basis, security measures, and breach notification. Key Difference: GDPR has more detailed requirements (records, DPIAs, DPOs).

subsections.title: Lawful Bases for Processing
subsections.content:
Processing is lawful only if based on:
- Consent of the data subject
- Performance of a contract
- Compliance with legal obligations
- Protection of vital interests
- Performance of a task in public interest
- Legitimate interests of the controller or third party
subsections.laymanExplanation: You can only process personal data if you have one of six lawful bases: (1) Consent - Person agreed. (2) Contract - Needed to fulfill a contract. (3) Legal Obligation - Required by law. (4) Vital Interests - To protect someone's life. (5) Public Interest - For public tasks. (6) Legitimate Interests - Your legitimate business interests (with balancing test). You must identify which basis applies before processing. This ensures data isn't processed without a valid reason.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 4: Similar requirement for lawful purpose (consent or legitimate uses). Key Similarity: Both require lawful basis before processing. Key Difference: GDPR explicitly lists all six bases, while DPDPA uses broader 'legitimate uses'.

subsections.title: Conditions for Consent
subsections.content: Where processing is based on consent, the controller must be able to demonstrate consent, and consent must be easily withdrawable.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 7(1) Where processing is based on consent, the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.

(3) The data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time. The withdrawal of consent shall not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal.

(4) When assessing whether consent is freely given, utmost account shall be taken of whether, inter alia, the performance of a contract, including the provision of a service, is conditional on consent to the processing of personal data that is not necessary for the performance of that contract.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If you rely on consent: (1) You must prove it - Keep records showing the person consented. (2) Easy withdrawal - People must be able to withdraw consent easily (like an unsubscribe button). (3) Not conditional - You can't make consent a condition for services unless the data is necessary for that service. This prevents 'consent or no service' situations where consent isn't truly free.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 6: Similar consent requirements. Key Similarity: Both require demonstrable consent that can be withdrawn.

subsections.title: Child's Consent
subsections.content: For children under 16, consent must be given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility.
subsections.bareActText: Article 8(1) Where point (a) of Article 6(1) applies, in relation to the offer of information society services directly to a child, the processing of the personal data of a child shall be lawful where the child is at least 16 years old. Where the child is below the age of 16 years, such processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorised by the holder of parental responsibility over the child.
subsections.laymanExplanation: For online services offered directly to children: (1) 16+ years - Children 16 and older can consent themselves. (2) Under 16 - Need parental consent. This protects children who may not understand what they're agreeing to. Member states can lower the age to 13.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar protection for children's data. Key Similarity: Both require parental consent for children.

subsections.title: Transparent Information
subsections.content: Controllers must provide information in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 12(1) The controller shall take appropriate measures to provide any information referred to in Articles 13 and 14 and any communication under Articles 15 to 22 and 34 relating to processing to the data subject in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language, in particular for any information addressed specifically to a child.

(2) The controller shall facilitate the exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15 to 22.

(3) The controller shall provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15 to 22 to the data subject without undue delay and in any event within one month of receipt of the request.
subsections.laymanExplanation: You must: (1) Use plain language - No legal jargon. Information must be clear and understandable. (2) Make it accessible - Easy to find and read. (3) Respond quickly - Answer data subject requests within one month. (4) Help people exercise rights - Make it easy for people to use their GDPR rights. This ensures people actually understand what's happening with their data.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 5: Similar transparency requirements. Key Similarity: Both require clear, understandable information.

subsections.title: Information to be Provided
subsections.content: Controllers must provide specific information when collecting data directly (Article 13) or indirectly (Article 14).
subsections.laymanExplanation: When you collect data, you must tell people: (1) Who you are - Your identity and contact details. (2) Why - Purpose and legal basis. (3) Who gets it - Recipients of the data. (4) How long - Storage period. (5) Their rights - What rights they have. (6) Complaints - How to complain. (7) Transfers - If you send data outside the EU. (8) Automated decisions - If you use algorithms. This must be provided when you collect data directly (Article 13) or when you get it from elsewhere (Article 14).
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 5: Similar notice requirements. Key Similarity: Both require providing information about processing.

subsections.title: Responsibility of Controller
subsections.content: Controllers must implement appropriate measures to ensure and demonstrate compliance.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 24(1) Taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the risks of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation.

(2) Those measures shall be reviewed and updated where necessary.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Controllers must: (1) Implement measures - Put in place technical and organizational measures to ensure compliance. (2) Demonstrate compliance - Be able to show you're complying (accountability principle). (3) Review and update - Regularly review and update your measures. The measures must be appropriate to the risks - higher risk processing needs stronger measures.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8: Similar accountability requirements. Key Similarity: Both require controllers to ensure compliance.

subsections.title: Processor Requirements
subsections.content: Processors must process only on documented instructions and implement security measures.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 28(1) Where processing is to be carried out on behalf of a controller, the controller shall use only processors providing sufficient guarantees to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures.

(2) The processor shall not engage another processor without prior specific or general written authorisation of the controller.

(3) Processing by a processor shall be governed by a contract or other legal act that sets out the subject-matter and duration of the processing, the nature and purpose of the processing, the type of personal data and categories of data subjects and the obligations and rights of the controller.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Processors must: (1) Follow instructions - Only process as instructed by the controller. (2) Have a contract - Must have a written contract (data processing agreement) setting out responsibilities. (3) Implement security - Put in place appropriate security measures. (4) Get authorization - Can't use sub-processors without controller's permission. (5) Assist controller - Help controller comply with GDPR obligations.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 9: Similar processor obligations. Key Similarity: Both require processors to follow controller's instructions and implement security.

subsections.title: Security of Processing
subsections.content: Controllers and processors must implement appropriate technical and organizational security measures.
subsections.laymanExplanation: You must implement security measures appropriate to the risk: (1) Pseudonymisation/Encryption - Use techniques to protect data. (2) Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability - Ensure data is kept confidential, accurate, and available. (3) Resilience - Systems must be able to recover from incidents. (4) Regular testing - Test and evaluate your security measures regularly. Higher risk data (like health data) needs stronger security.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8(5): Similar security safeguard requirements. Key Similarity: Both require appropriate security measures.

subsections.title: Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)
subsections.content: Controllers must conduct DPIAs for high-risk processing operations, including AI systems that process personal data.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 35(1) Where a type of processing in particular using new technologies, and taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing, is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller shall, prior to the processing, carry out an assessment of the impact of the envisaged processing operations on the protection of personal data.

(2) A single assessment may address a set of similar processing operations that present similar high risks.

(3) The controller shall seek the advice of the data protection officer, where designated, when carrying out a data protection impact assessment.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Before high-risk processing, you must: (1) Assess risks - Identify what could go wrong and how it affects people. (2) Identify measures - Figure out what measures you'll take to reduce risks. (3) Document it - Keep records of your assessment. (4) Consult DPO - Get advice from your DPO if you have one. High-risk includes: large-scale processing of sensitive data, systematic monitoring, automated decision-making. This helps prevent problems before they happen.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: No explicit DPIA requirement, but similar risk assessment concepts. Key Similarity: Both recognize need for risk assessment.

subsections.title: Prior Consultation
subsections.content: Controllers must consult the supervisory authority before high-risk processing if a DPIA indicates high risk.
subsections.bareActText: Article 36(1) The controller shall consult the supervisory authority prior to processing where a data protection impact assessment under Article 35 indicates that the processing would result in a high risk in the absence of measures taken by the controller to mitigate the risk.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If your DPIA shows high risk that you can't mitigate, you must: (1) Consult authority - Talk to your supervisory authority before starting processing. (2) Get advice - They'll advise you on how to proceed. (3) Wait for response - They have 8 weeks to respond. This ensures authorities can prevent risky processing before it starts.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: No explicit prior consultation requirement. Key Similarity: Both recognize need for regulatory oversight of high-risk processing.

subsections.title: Notification Obligation Regarding Rectification or Erasure
subsections.content: Controllers must notify recipients of personal data about rectification, erasure, or restriction of processing.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 19 - Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing

The controller shall communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1) and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort. The controller shall inform the data subject about those recipients if the data subject requests it.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If you correct, delete, or restrict someone's data, you must: (1) Tell recipients - Notify anyone you've shared the data with about the correction/deletion/restriction. (2) Unless impossible - You don't have to if it's impossible or would take too much effort. (3) Tell the person - If they ask, tell them who you notified. This ensures that if you fix or delete someone's data, all the places you've shared it also get updated.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 12: Similar requirement to notify about corrections/erasure. Key Similarity: Both require notifying recipients of corrections/deletions.

subsections.title: Data Breach Notification
subsections.content:
Controllers must notify:
- Supervisory authority within 72 hours of becoming aware of a breach
- Data subjects without undue delay if the breach is likely to result in a high risk to their rights and freedoms
subsections.bareActText:
Article 33(1) In the case of a personal data breach, the controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority.

Article 34(1) When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller shall communicate the personal data breach to the data subject without undue delay.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If a data breach happens, companies must: (1) Tell authorities - Within 72 hours of discovering the breach. (2) Tell affected people - If the breach is high risk, tell them without delay. This ensures people can take steps to protect themselves (like changing passwords). The 72-hour timeline is strict - companies must act quickly.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8(6): Similar breach notification requirement, though DPDPA doesn't specify exact timeline. Key Similarity: Both require breach notification. Key Difference: GDPR specifies 72-hour timeline, while DPDPA leaves it to be prescribed.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding obligations helps ensure compliance with GDPR.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
What Are the Key Obligations?

Lawful Basis: You can only process data if you have a valid reason (consent, contract, legal requirement, etc.)

Principles: Data must be processed lawfully, fairly, transparently, for specific purposes, minimized, accurate, and secure

Privacy by Design: Build privacy into systems from the start

Records: Keep records of what data you process and why

Impact Assessments: Assess risks for high-risk processing

Breach Notification: Tell authorities within 72 hours and affected people if high risk

Data Protection Officer: Appoint a DPO for certain organizations

Why This Matters: These obligations ensure companies handle data responsibly. Violations can result in fines up to €20 million or 4% of annual turnover.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR obligations can be compared with similar provisions.
subsections.crossMapping:
DPDPA Comparison:
- GDPR Lawful Basis ≈ DPDPA Lawful Purpose (Section 4)
- GDPR Security Measures ≈ DPDPA Security Safeguards (Section 8)
- GDPR Breach Notification ≈ DPDPA Breach Notification (Section 8(6))
- GDPR has more detailed requirements (Records, DPIAs, DPOs) that DPDPA doesn't explicitly include

Key Takeaway: GDPR has more comprehensive obligations, while DPDPA is more streamlined. Both require lawful basis, security measures, and breach notification.

dataBreach.title: Personal Data Breach
dataBreach.content: A personal data breach means a breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorized disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed.
dataBreach.bareActText:
Article 4(12) 'personal data breach' means a breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed;

Article 33 - Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority

(1) In the case of a personal data breach, the controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority competent in accordance with Article 55, unless the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.

Article 34 - Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject

(1) When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller shall communicate the personal data breach to the data subject without undue delay.
dataBreach.laymanExplanation: A personal data breach is when something goes wrong with your personal data - it gets accessed by someone who shouldn't have it, lost, stolen, accidentally shared, or damaged. Companies must: (1) Tell authorities - Within 72 hours of discovering the breach (very strict timeline). (2) Tell you - If the breach is high risk, they must tell you without delay so you can protect yourself. This ensures you know when your data is compromised and can take action (like changing passwords or monitoring for fraud).
dataBreach.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8(6): Similar breach notification requirement, though DPDPA doesn't specify exact timeline. IT Act: No explicit breach notification requirement. Key Similarity: Both GDPR and DPDPA require breach notification. Key Difference: GDPR specifies 72-hour timeline, while DPDPA leaves it to be prescribed.

subsections.title: Notification to Supervisory Authority
subsections.content: In case of a personal data breach, the controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority, unless the breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
subsections.bareActText: Article 33(1) In the case of a personal data breach, the controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority competent in accordance with Article 55, unless the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Companies must tell the supervisory authority (like ICO in UK, CNIL in France) within 72 hours of discovering a data breach. This is a very strict timeline - companies must act quickly. The notification must include details about the breach, what data was affected, and what they're doing about it. If they can't provide all details within 72 hours, they can provide initial notification and follow up later.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8(6): Similar requirement but no specific timeline. Key Similarity: Both require breach notification to authorities. Key Difference: GDPR specifies 72-hour timeline.

subsections.title: Communication to Data Subject
subsections.content: When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller shall communicate the personal data breach to the data subject without undue delay.
subsections.bareActText: Article 34(1) When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, the controller shall communicate the personal data breach to the data subject without undue delay.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If a data breach is high risk (could cause serious harm like identity theft), companies must tell affected people without delay. They must explain what happened, what data was affected, what risks you face, and what they're doing about it. This helps you take steps to protect yourself (like changing passwords or monitoring accounts).
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8(6): Similar requirement to notify affected individuals. Key Similarity: Both require notification to affected individuals for high-risk breaches.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding data breach requirements helps you know what to expect.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
What Is a Data Breach?

A data breach is when your personal data gets into the wrong hands - accessed by hackers, lost, stolen, accidentally shared, or damaged.

What Companies Must Do:

Tell Authorities: Within 72 hours of discovering the breach (very strict timeline)

Tell You: If the breach is high risk, they must tell you without delay

What You Should Do:

If you're notified of a breach:
- Change passwords immediately
- Monitor accounts for suspicious activity
- Consider credit monitoring services
- Be cautious of phishing attempts

Why This Matters: Breach notification helps you take steps to protect yourself from identity theft or fraud. The 72-hour timeline ensures companies act quickly.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR breach requirements can be compared with similar provisions.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 8(6): Similar breach notification requirement, though DPDPA doesn't specify exact timeline. IT Act: No explicit breach notification requirement. Key Takeaway: GDPR's breach notification requirements are more prescriptive (72-hour timeline) than DPDPA, though both require notification to authorities and affected individuals.

penalties.title: Penalties
penalties.content:
The GDPR prescribes administrative fines:

1. For Infringements of Basic Principles: Up to €20,000,000 or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher.

2. For Other Infringements: Up to €10,000,000 or 2% of total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher.

3. Compensation: Data subjects have the right to receive compensation for material or non-material damage resulting from infringement of the GDPR.
penalties.laymanExplanation: The GDPR has serious penalties: (1) Serious Violations - Up to €20 million or 4% of annual turnover (whichever is higher) for violations of basic principles, rights, or transfers. For large companies, 4% of turnover can be billions. (2) Other Violations - Up to €10 million or 2% of turnover for other violations. (3) Compensation - People can claim compensation for harm caused by violations. When deciding penalties, authorities consider how serious it was, whether it was intentional, how long it lasted, and what steps were taken to mitigate. These penalties ensure companies take GDPR seriously.
penalties.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 33: Similar penalty structure with fines up to ₹200 crores. EU AI Act Article 99: Similar turnover-based penalties. Key Similarity: All use significant penalties to ensure compliance. Key Difference: GDPR uses turnover percentage (can be very high for large companies), while DPDPA uses fixed maximum amounts.

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding penalties helps you know what happens when companies violate GDPR.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
What Are the Penalties?

The GDPR has serious penalties:

Serious Violations: Up to €20 million or 4% of annual turnover (whichever is higher) for:
- Violations of basic principles (lawfulness, consent, etc.)
- Violations of data subject rights
- Unlawful data transfers

Other Violations: Up to €10 million or 2% of turnover for:
- Other compliance failures

For Large Companies: The turnover percentage can result in billions in fines

Compensation: People can claim compensation for harm caused by violations

How Penalties Are Decided:

Authorities consider:
- How serious the violation was
- Whether it was intentional or negligent
- How long it lasted
- What steps were taken to mitigate

Why This Matters: These penalties ensure companies take GDPR seriously. For large companies, the turnover percentage can result in massive fines, which encourages compliance.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR penalties can be compared with similar frameworks.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 33: Similar penalty structure with fines up to ₹200 crores for serious violations. EU AI Act Article 99: Similar turnover-based penalties (up to 7% of turnover). Key Similarity: All use significant penalties to ensure compliance. Key Difference: GDPR uses turnover percentage (can be very high for large companies), while DPDPA uses fixed maximum amounts. GDPR's 4% maximum is higher than DPDPA's fixed ₹200 crores for very large companies.
citations: Articles 82-83, GDPR; Section 33, DPDPA 2023; Article 99, EU AI Act

regulatory.title: Supervisory Authorities and Regulatory Framework
regulatory.content:
The GDPR establishes a comprehensive regulatory framework:

1. Supervisory Authorities (Articles 51-59): Each Member State establishes independent public authorities with powers to monitor, investigate, and enforce GDPR compliance.

2. Cooperation and Consistency (Articles 60-67): Supervisory authorities cooperate to ensure consistent application, with a lead supervisory authority for cross-border processing.

3. European Data Protection Board (Articles 68-76): The EDPB ensures consistent application across the Union and provides guidance.

4. Powers of Supervisory Authorities (Articles 57-58): Authorities have investigative, corrective, and advisory powers, including the power to impose fines.

5. International Cooperation (Article 50): Supervisory authorities cooperate with third countries and international organizations.
regulatory.laymanExplanation: The GDPR establishes a comprehensive regulatory framework: (1) Supervisory Authorities - Each EU country has independent authorities (like ICO in UK, CNIL in France, BfDI in Germany) that monitor and enforce GDPR. They have powers to investigate, issue warnings, impose fines, and order compliance. (2) Powers - Authorities can audit companies, access data, order corrections, ban processing, and impose fines up to €20 million or 4% of turnover. (3) Cooperation - For cross-border cases, authorities cooperate with a 'lead supervisory authority' coordinating the case. (4) European Data Protection Board (EDPB) - Coordinates between national authorities, resolves disputes, and provides guidance to ensure consistent application across the EU. (5) International Cooperation - Authorities cooperate with third countries and international organizations. This framework ensures consistent enforcement while allowing local handling of issues.
regulatory.crossMapping: DPDPA Data Protection Board: Similar regulatory body for data protection, though DPDPA has one national board while GDPR has multiple national authorities. EU AI Act European AI Board: Similar EU-level coordination body. Key Similarity: All establish regulatory bodies for oversight and enforcement. Key Difference: GDPR has decentralized structure (one authority per member state), while DPDPA has centralized structure (one national board).

subsections.title: Layman Explanation
subsections.content: Understanding the regulatory framework helps you know who enforces GDPR and how to seek help.
subsections.laymanExplanation:
Who Enforces GDPR?

The GDPR establishes a multi-level regulatory framework:

Supervisory Authorities: Each EU country has independent authorities (like ICO in UK, CNIL in France) that:
- Monitor compliance
- Investigate violations (can audit companies, access data)
- Impose penalties (warnings, reprimands, fines up to €20M or 4% turnover)
- Order compliance (can order companies to fix problems, delete data, stop processing)
- Hear complaints from data subjects
- Provide guidance and advice

Powers of Authorities:
- Investigative: Can audit companies, access data, enter premises
- Corrective: Can issue warnings, reprimands, order compliance, ban processing, impose fines
- Advisory: Can provide opinions, approve codes of conduct, accredit certification bodies

European Data Protection Board (EDPB): Coordinates between national authorities, resolves disputes, and ensures consistent application across the EU

Cooperation: For cross-border cases, authorities cooperate with a 'lead supervisory authority' coordinating the investigation

How to Use the Framework:

If a company violates your data rights:
1. File a complaint with your country's supervisory authority
2. The authority will investigate
3. The authority can order the company to fix the problem or pay a penalty
4. For cross-border cases, authorities cooperate through the EDPB

Why This Matters: This framework ensures consistent enforcement across the EU while allowing local handling of issues. You can seek help from your country's authority.

subsections.title: Cross-Mapping
subsections.content: GDPR's regulatory framework can be compared with similar structures.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Data Protection Board: Similar regulatory body for data protection, though DPDPA has one national board while GDPR has multiple national authorities with EU-level coordination. Both have powers to investigate, impose penalties, and order compliance. EU AI Act European AI Board: Similar EU-level coordination body. Key Takeaway: GDPR's decentralized structure (one authority per member state with EU-level coordination) is different from DPDPA's centralized structure (one national board), though both provide comprehensive regulatory oversight with similar powers.
citations: Articles 51-76, GDPR; DPDPA 2023; EU AI Act

remedies.title: Remedies, Liability and Penalties
remedies.content:
The GDPR provides comprehensive remedies for data subjects:

1. Right to Lodge a Complaint (Article 77): Data subjects have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.

2. Right to an Effective Judicial Remedy (Article 78): Data subjects have the right to an effective judicial remedy against a legally binding decision of a supervisory authority.

3. Right to an Effective Judicial Remedy Against Controller or Processor (Article 79): Data subjects have the right to an effective judicial remedy where they consider that their rights have been infringed.

4. Representation of Data Subjects (Article 80): Data subjects may be represented by not-for-profit bodies, organisations or associations.

5. Right to Compensation and Liability (Article 82): Data subjects have the right to receive compensation for material or non-material damage resulting from infringement of the GDPR.
remedies.bareActText:
Article 77 - Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority

(1) Without prejudice to any other administrative or judicial remedy, every data subject shall have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, in particular in the Member State of his or her habitual residence, place of work or place of the alleged infringement if the data subject considers that the processing of personal data relating to him or her infringes this Regulation.

(2) The supervisory authority with which the complaint has been lodged shall inform the complainant on the progress and the outcome of the complaint including the possibility of a judicial remedy pursuant to Article 78.

Article 78 - Right to an effective judicial remedy against a supervisory authority

(1) Without prejudice to any other administrative or non-judicial remedy, each natural or legal person shall have the right to an effective judicial remedy against a legally binding decision of a supervisory authority concerning them.

(2) Without prejudice to any other administrative or non-judicial remedy, each data subject shall have the right to a an effective judicial remedy where the supervisory authority which is competent pursuant to Articles 55 and 56 does not handle a complaint or does not inform the data subject within three months on the progress or outcome of the complaint lodged pursuant to Article 77.

(3) Proceedings against a supervisory authority shall be brought before the courts of the Member State where the supervisory authority is established.

Article 79 - Right to an effective judicial remedy against a controller or processor

(1) Without prejudice to any available administrative or non-judicial remedy, including the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority pursuant to Article 77, each data subject shall have the right to an effective judicial remedy where he or she considers that his or her rights under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing of his or her personal data in non-compliance with this Regulation.

(2) Proceedings against a controller or a processor shall be brought before the courts of the Member State where the controller or processor has an establishment. Alternatively, such proceedings may be brought before the courts of the Member State where the data subject has his or her habitual residence, unless the controller or processor is a public authority of a Member State acting in the exercise of its public powers.

Article 80 - Representation of data subjects

(1) The data subject shall have the right to mandate a not-for-profit body, organisation or association which has been properly constituted in accordance with the law of a Member State, has statutory objectives which are in the public interest, and is active in the field of the protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms with regard to the protection of their personal data to lodge the complaint on his or her behalf with a supervisory authority, to exercise the right to a judicial remedy on behalf of data subjects referred to in Articles 77, 78 and 79, and to exercise the right to receive compensation referred to in Article 82 on behalf of data subjects, provided that the data subject has given the mandate.

(2) Member States may provide that any body, organisation or association referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article, independently of a data subject's mandate, has the right to lodge, in that Member State, a complaint with the supervisory authority which is competent pursuant to Article 77 and to exercise the rights referred to in Articles 78 and 79 if it considers that the rights of a data subject under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing.

Article 82 - Right to compensation and liability

(1) Any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this Regulation shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered.

(2) Any controller involved in processing shall be liable for the damage caused by processing which infringes this Regulation. A processor shall be liable for the damage caused by processing only where it has not complied with obligations of this Regulation specifically directed to processors or where it has acted outside or contrary to lawful instructions of the controller.

(3) A controller or processor shall be exempted from liability if it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.

(4) Where more than one controller or processor, or both a controller and a processor, are involved in the same processing and where they are, under paragraphs 2 and 3, responsible for any damage caused by the processing, each controller or processor shall be held liable for the entire damage in order to ensure effective compensation of the data subject.

(5) Where a controller or processor has, in accordance with paragraph 4, paid full compensation for the damage suffered, that controller or processor shall be entitled to claim back from the other controllers or processors involved in the same processing that part of the compensation corresponding to their part of responsibility for the damage, in accordance with the conditions set out in paragraph 2.
remedies.laymanExplanation: The GDPR gives you multiple ways to get help if your data rights are violated: (1) Complain to Authority - You can file a complaint with your country's supervisory authority (like ICO, CNIL). They must investigate and tell you the outcome. (2) Go to Court - You can sue companies that violate your rights, or challenge decisions by supervisory authorities. You can sue in your country or where the company is located. (3) Get Representation - Non-profit organizations can help you file complaints and go to court on your behalf. (4) Get Compensation - You can claim compensation for any harm (financial or emotional) caused by GDPR violations. Companies are liable for damage they cause. If multiple companies are involved, they're all responsible. This gives you strong protection and multiple ways to enforce your rights.
remedies.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 13: Similar right to grievance redressal. DPDPA Section 33: Similar compensation provisions. Key Similarity: Both provide multiple remedies for data subjects. Key Difference: GDPR has more detailed judicial remedies and allows representation by organizations.

subsections.title: Right to Lodge a Complaint
subsections.content: Data subjects have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 77(1) Without prejudice to any other administrative or judicial remedy, every data subject shall have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, in particular in the Member State of his or her habitual residence, place of work or place of the alleged infringement if the data subject considers that the processing of personal data relating to him or her infringes this Regulation.

(2) The supervisory authority with which the complaint has been lodged shall inform the complainant on the progress and the outcome of the complaint including the possibility of a judicial remedy pursuant to Article 78.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If a company violates your data rights, you can: (1) File a complaint - With your country's supervisory authority (like ICO, CNIL). You can complain in your country, where you work, or where the violation happened. (2) Get updates - The authority must tell you what's happening with your complaint. (3) Free - Complaints are free. This is the easiest way to get help.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 13: Similar grievance redressal mechanism. Key Similarity: Both allow complaints to regulatory authorities.

subsections.title: Right to an Effective Judicial Remedy
subsections.content: Data subjects have the right to an effective judicial remedy against controllers, processors, or supervisory authorities.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 78(1) Without prejudice to any other administrative or non-judicial remedy, each natural or legal person shall have the right to an effective judicial remedy against a legally binding decision of a supervisory authority concerning them.

Article 79(1) Without prejudice to any available administrative or non-judicial remedy, including the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority pursuant to Article 77, each data subject shall have the right to an effective judicial remedy where he or she considers that his or her rights under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing of his or her personal data in non-compliance with this Regulation.
subsections.laymanExplanation: You can go to court if: (1) Company violates your rights - You can sue the company in your country or where the company is located. (2) Authority makes wrong decision - You can challenge decisions by supervisory authorities in court. (3) Authority doesn't act - If the authority doesn't handle your complaint within 3 months, you can go to court. Courts must provide effective remedies - they can't just ignore your case.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar judicial remedies available. Key Similarity: Both provide access to courts for violations.

subsections.title: Representation of Data Subjects
subsections.content: Data subjects may be represented by not-for-profit bodies, organisations or associations.
subsections.bareActText: Article 80(1) The data subject shall have the right to mandate a not-for-profit body, organisation or association which has been properly constituted in accordance with the law of a Member State, has statutory objectives which are in the public interest, and is active in the field of the protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms with regard to the protection of their personal data to lodge the complaint on his or her behalf with a supervisory authority, to exercise the right to a judicial remedy on behalf of data subjects referred to in Articles 77, 78 and 79, and to exercise the right to receive compensation referred to in Article 82 on behalf of data subjects, provided that the data subject has given the mandate.
subsections.laymanExplanation: You don't have to fight alone: (1) Get help - Non-profit organizations (like privacy advocacy groups) can help you file complaints and go to court. (2) They act for you - They can represent you in proceedings. (3) Must be authorized - You must give them permission. (4) Some countries allow more - Some EU countries allow these organizations to act even without your permission if they see violations. This makes it easier for people to enforce their rights.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar representation concepts. Key Similarity: Both allow representation in proceedings.

subsections.title: Right to Compensation and Liability
subsections.content: Data subjects have the right to receive compensation for material or non-material damage resulting from infringement of the GDPR.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 82(1) Any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this Regulation shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered.

(2) Any controller involved in processing shall be liable for the damage caused by processing which infringes this Regulation. A processor shall be liable for the damage caused by processing only where it has not complied with obligations of this Regulation specifically directed to processors or where it has acted outside or contrary to lawful instructions of the controller.
