(4) Where more than one controller or processor, or both a controller and a processor, are involved in the same processing and where they are, under paragraphs 2 and 3, responsible for any damage caused by the processing, each controller or processor shall be held liable for the entire damage in order to ensure effective compensation of the data subject.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If a company violates GDPR and causes you harm, you can: (1) Claim compensation - For financial loss (material damage) or emotional distress (non-material damage). You don't need to prove financial loss - emotional distress counts too. (2) Who's liable - Controllers are always liable. Processors are only liable if they break their obligations or act against instructions. (3) Multiple companies - If multiple companies are involved, they're all responsible. You can claim from any of them. (4) They can't escape - Companies can only avoid liability if they prove they're not responsible. This ensures you can get compensation when your rights are violated.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 33: Similar compensation provisions. Key Similarity: Both provide right to compensation for violations.

exemptions.title: Restrictions and Exemptions
exemptions.content:
The GDPR allows Member States to introduce restrictions and exemptions in specific situations:

1. Restrictions (Article 23): Member States may restrict the scope of certain obligations and rights by legislative measures.

2. Specific Processing Situations (Articles 84-86): The GDPR provides specific rules for processing in employment context, processing for archiving purposes, and obligations of secrecy.
exemptions.laymanExplanation: The GDPR allows some flexibility: (1) Restrictions - Member States can restrict certain GDPR rights (like access, erasure) for specific reasons like national security, law enforcement, or public interest. But restrictions must be necessary, proportionate, and respect fundamental rights. (2) Specific Situations - Special rules apply for: employment data, archiving, freedom of expression (journalism), and public access to documents. (3) Penalties - Member States can add their own penalties beyond GDPR fines. This balances data protection with other important interests like security, journalism, and public access to information.
exemptions.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 17: Similar exemptions for certain processing. Key Similarity: Both allow exemptions for specific purposes. Key Difference: GDPR allows Member States to introduce restrictions, while DPDPA has specific exemptions listed in the Act.

subsections.title: Restrictions on Rights and Obligations
subsections.content: Member States may restrict certain GDPR rights and obligations by legislative measures for specific purposes.
subsections.laymanExplanation: EU countries can restrict certain GDPR rights (like access, erasure) for important reasons: (1) National security - To protect the country. (2) Law enforcement - For police investigations. (3) Public interest - For important public purposes. (4) Judicial proceedings - For court cases. But restrictions must: (1) Be necessary and proportionate. (2) Respect fundamental rights. (3) Be in a law. This balances data protection with other important interests.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 17: Similar exemptions for law enforcement and security. Key Similarity: Both allow restrictions for security and law enforcement purposes.

subsections.title: Processing and Freedom of Expression
subsections.content: Member States must reconcile data protection with freedom of expression and information.
subsections.bareActText: Article 85(1) Member States shall by law reconcile the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation with the right to freedom of expression and information, including processing for journalistic purposes and the purposes of academic, artistic or literary expression.
subsections.laymanExplanation: EU countries must balance data protection with freedom of expression. This means: (1) Journalism - Journalists can process personal data for news reporting, even without consent. (2) Academic/Artistic - Researchers and artists have flexibility for their work. (3) Must be balanced - Countries must create laws that balance both rights. This ensures journalism and research can continue while protecting privacy.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar exemptions for journalism and research. Key Similarity: Both recognize need to balance privacy with freedom of expression.

specialCategories.title: Special Categories of Personal Data
specialCategories.content:
The GDPR provides special protection for sensitive personal data, including:

1. Processing of Special Categories (Article 9): Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation shall be prohibited, except in specific circumstances.

2. Criminal Convictions Data (Article 10): Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures may be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law.

3. Conditions for Processing: Special categories of data can only be processed if one of the specific conditions in Article 9(2) applies, such as explicit consent, employment law, vital interests, legitimate activities of foundations/associations, or public health.
specialCategories.laymanExplanation: The GDPR provides extra protection for sensitive personal data (called 'special categories'). This includes: race, ethnicity, political opinions, religious beliefs, trade union membership, genetic data, biometric data, health data, and sexual orientation. General Rule: Processing this sensitive data is prohibited unless you meet one of the specific exceptions. Exceptions Include: (1) Explicit consent - Person clearly agrees (higher standard than regular consent). (2) Employment law - Needed for employment purposes. (3) Vital interests - To protect someone's life. (4) Public health - For health purposes. (5) Legal claims - For legal proceedings. Criminal Data: Data about criminal convictions has even stricter rules - can only be processed under official authority or specific legal authorization. Why This Matters: Sensitive data needs extra protection because misuse can cause serious harm (discrimination, identity theft, etc.).
specialCategories.crossMapping: DPDPA: DPDPA doesn't explicitly categorize 'special categories' but requires higher security for sensitive personal data. Key Similarity: Both recognize that certain types of data need extra protection. Key Difference: GDPR explicitly lists special categories and prohibits processing unless exceptions apply, while DPDPA uses a more general approach.

subsections.title: Prohibition of Processing Special Categories
subsections.content: Processing of special categories of personal data is generally prohibited unless specific conditions are met.
subsections.bareActText: Article 9(1) Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation shall be prohibited.
subsections.laymanExplanation: As a general rule, you cannot process sensitive personal data (race, religion, health, etc.) unless you meet one of the specific exceptions. This is a strict prohibition - you need a valid legal reason to process this type of data.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar concept - sensitive data requires higher protection. Key Similarity: Both restrict processing of sensitive data.

subsections.title: Exceptions to the Prohibition
subsections.content: Special categories of data can be processed if one of the specific conditions in Article 9(2) applies.
subsections.laymanExplanation: You can process sensitive data if: (1) Explicit consent - Person clearly agrees (not just regular consent). (2) Employment - Needed for employment purposes. (3) Vital interests - To protect someone's life. (4) Public health - For health purposes. (5) Legal claims - For legal proceedings. (6) Public interest - For substantial public interest. (7) Research - For scientific research. These exceptions are strict - you must meet one of them exactly.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar exceptions for sensitive data processing. Key Similarity: Both allow processing of sensitive data under specific conditions.

subsections.title: Criminal Convictions Data
subsections.content: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences has additional restrictions.
subsections.bareActText: Article 10 Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects. Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Data about criminal convictions has even stricter rules. It can only be processed: (1) Under official authority - By government/law enforcement. (2) With legal authorization - When specifically authorized by law. Criminal records are highly sensitive and need the highest level of protection.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar restrictions on criminal data. Key Similarity: Both restrict processing of criminal conviction data.

dataTransfers.title: Transfers of Personal Data to Third Countries
dataTransfers.content:
The GDPR regulates transfers of personal data to countries outside the European Union (third countries):

1. General Principle (Article 44): Any transfer of personal data to a third country or an international organisation shall take place only if the conditions laid down in this Chapter are complied with.

2. Adequacy Decision (Article 45): A transfer may take place where the Commission has decided that the third country ensures an adequate level of protection.

3. Appropriate Safeguards (Article 46): In the absence of an adequacy decision, transfers may take place if appropriate safeguards are provided, such as binding corporate rules, standard contractual clauses, or codes of conduct.

4. Derogations (Article 49): In the absence of an adequacy decision or appropriate safeguards, transfers may take place under specific derogations, such as explicit consent or performance of a contract.
dataTransfers.laymanExplanation: The GDPR strictly controls when you can send personal data outside the EU (to 'third countries'). General Rule: You can only transfer data if you meet specific conditions. Three Main Ways: (1) Adequacy Decision - The EU has decided the country has adequate protection (like Japan, UK). (2) Appropriate Safeguards - You use approved safeguards like standard contractual clauses, binding corporate rules, or certification. (3) Derogations - In specific situations like explicit consent or performance of a contract. Why This Matters: EU data protection standards are high. The GDPR ensures your data is protected even when sent outside the EU. Without proper safeguards, transfers are illegal.
dataTransfers.crossMapping: DPDPA Section 16: Similar restrictions on cross-border transfers, requiring government approval for certain transfers. Key Similarity: Both restrict international data transfers. Key Difference: GDPR uses adequacy decisions and safeguards, while DPDPA uses government approval mechanism.

subsections.title: General Principle for Transfers
subsections.content: Any transfer of personal data to a third country must comply with the conditions laid down in Chapter V.
subsections.bareActText: Article 44 Any transfer of personal data which are undergoing processing or are intended for processing after transfer to a third country or to an international organisation shall take place only if, subject to the other provisions of this Regulation, the conditions laid down in this Chapter are complied with by the controller and processor.
subsections.laymanExplanation: You can only transfer personal data outside the EU if you follow the GDPR's transfer rules. This is a strict requirement - you can't just send data anywhere. You must use one of the approved mechanisms.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar requirement for cross-border transfers. Key Similarity: Both require compliance with transfer conditions.

subsections.title: Adequacy Decision
subsections.content: Transfers may take place where the Commission has decided that the third country ensures an adequate level of protection.
subsections.bareActText: Article 45(1) A transfer of personal data to a third country or an international organisation may take place where the Commission has decided that the third country, a territory or one or more specified sectors within that third country, or the international organisation in question ensures an adequate level of protection. Such a transfer shall not require any specific authorisation.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If the EU has decided a country has 'adequate' data protection (like Japan, UK, Switzerland), you can transfer data there without additional safeguards. The EU regularly reviews these adequacy decisions.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar concept of approved countries/territories. Key Similarity: Both recognize certain jurisdictions as having adequate protection.

subsections.title: Appropriate Safeguards
subsections.content: In the absence of an adequacy decision, transfers may take place if appropriate safeguards are provided.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If there's no adequacy decision, you can still transfer data if you use approved safeguards: (1) Standard Contractual Clauses - EU-approved contracts. (2) Binding Corporate Rules - Internal rules for multinational companies. (3) Certification - Approved certification schemes. (4) Codes of Conduct - Approved industry codes. These safeguards ensure data is protected even in countries without adequacy decisions.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar requirement for safeguards in cross-border transfers. Key Similarity: Both require appropriate safeguards for international transfers.

subsections.title: Derogations for Specific Situations
subsections.content: In the absence of adequacy decisions or appropriate safeguards, transfers may take place under specific derogations.
subsections.laymanExplanation: In limited situations, you can transfer data even without adequacy or safeguards: (1) Explicit consent - Person clearly agrees after being warned of risks. (2) Contract performance - Needed to fulfill a contract. (3) Public interest - For important public reasons. (4) Legal claims - For legal proceedings. (5) Vital interests - To protect someone's life. These are exceptions - use them carefully and only when necessary.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar exceptions for cross-border transfers. Key Similarity: Both allow transfers under specific exceptions.

codesAndCertification.title: Codes of Conduct and Certification
codesAndCertification.content:
The GDPR encourages the use of codes of conduct and certification mechanisms to demonstrate compliance:

1. Codes of Conduct (Articles 40-41): Associations and bodies may prepare codes of conduct to specify how the GDPR applies in specific sectors or contexts.

2. Certification (Articles 42-43): Controllers and processors may obtain certification to demonstrate compliance with the GDPR.

3. Monitoring Bodies: Codes of conduct must be monitored by accredited bodies to ensure compliance.
codesAndCertification.laymanExplanation: The GDPR encourages voluntary compliance tools: Codes of Conduct - Industry associations can create sector-specific guidelines (like for healthcare, finance) that specify how GDPR applies in their industry. These codes help companies understand GDPR requirements in their specific context. Certification - Companies can get certified to show they comply with GDPR. This is like a 'seal of approval' that demonstrates good data protection practices. Benefits: (1) Shows you take compliance seriously. (2) Can reduce fines if you have certification. (3) Builds trust with customers. (4) Helps with international transfers. Why This Matters: These tools make GDPR compliance more practical and help companies demonstrate their commitment to data protection.
codesAndCertification.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar concept of industry codes and certification. Key Similarity: Both encourage voluntary compliance mechanisms. Key Difference: GDPR has more detailed framework for codes and certification.

subsections.title: Codes of Conduct
subsections.content: Associations may prepare codes of conduct to specify how the GDPR applies in specific sectors.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 40(1) The Member States, the supervisory authorities, the Board and the Commission shall encourage the drawing up of codes of conduct intended to contribute to the proper application of this Regulation, taking account of the specific features of the various processing sectors and the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.

(2) Associations and other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors may prepare codes of conduct, or amend or extend such codes, for the purpose of specifying the application of this Regulation.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Industry associations (like healthcare, finance, tech) can create codes of conduct that explain how GDPR applies in their specific sector. These codes help companies in that industry understand GDPR requirements in practical terms. Codes must be approved by supervisory authorities.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar encouragement of industry codes. Key Similarity: Both support sector-specific guidance.

subsections.title: Certification Mechanisms
subsections.content: Controllers and processors may obtain certification to demonstrate compliance with the GDPR.
subsections.bareActText:
Article 42(1) The Member States, the supervisory authorities, the Board and the Commission shall encourage, in particular at Union level, the establishment of data protection certification mechanisms and of data protection seals and marks, for the purpose of demonstrating compliance with this Regulation of processing operations by controllers and processors.

(3) The certification shall be voluntary and available via a process that is transparent.

(4) A controller or processor subject to this Regulation may adhere to a certification mechanism. The extent to which certification mechanisms are used may be taken into account in order to determine the amount of a fine in accordance with Article 83(2)(k).
subsections.laymanExplanation: Companies can get certified to show they comply with GDPR. This is voluntary but can: (1) Demonstrate compliance. (2) Reduce fines if you have certification. (3) Build customer trust. (4) Help with international transfers. Certification must be transparent and from accredited bodies.
subsections.crossMapping: DPDPA: Similar certification mechanisms. Key Similarity: Both support certification as a compliance tool.
